newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Foreign interest cuts Kazakh T-bill yields-dealers.
newsitem.headline: Foreign interest cuts Kazakh T-bill yields-dealers.

text.p: Yields on Kazakh three- and six-month Treasury bills could edge down further at auctions next week due to active buying by foreigners, despite recent falls in yields, dealers said on Thursday.
Kazakhstan's finance ministry is offering 700 million tenge of six-month MKM discount T-bills on Monday and 550 million tenge of three-month paper on Tuesday.
The yield on three-month T-bills fell to 18.02 percent annual at their last auction on May 6 from 20.04 percent on April 29. Demand was around 2.22 billion tenge against 600 million on offer.
The yield on six-month paper fell to 22.97 percent at the last auction on April 28 from 24.52 percent on April 15. Demand was 2.97 billion against 650 million on offer.

Foreign investors are entitled to buy just 15 percent of three-month T-bill issues and 30 percent of six-month paper but dealers said their aggressive participation in auctions was one of the main reasons behind steadily falling yields.

"The situation on the T-bill market is such that T-bill yields are programmed to continue falling. The tenge rate is stable, and yields of 18-19 percent annual suit foreign investors," an Agroprombank dealer said.
The tenge has been fluctuating at around 75 per dollar since January.
Economy Minister Umirzak Shukeyev told a recent cabinet meeting the government was planning further falls of T-bill yields to stimulate investment credits to the economy.

"It (lower yields) is very good for the government which wants local banks to finance the economy and not speculate on T-bill yields... But on the other hand, the percentage of overdue debts to banks on such (investment) loans is too high," the Agroprombank dealer said.
But the strong foreign buying is upsetting some locals.
"Foreigners are too aggressively slashing down yields," said Denis Fedosenko of Kazkommertsbank.
Another dealer said several large Kazakh banks, facing tough foreign competition, were planning to transfer their operations to other T-bill markets within the former Soviet Union.
Yet some dealers gave other reasons for lower yields.
"I think, too many tenge on the market is the reason," said Lyudmila Pogulyayeva of ABN AMRO Bank Kazakhstan.
Last week the National Bank repaid several note and T-bills totalling around 2.5 billion tenge but held no auctions of its short-term notes issued to sterilise the money supply and support the tenge.
And dealers said the falling yield trend could be stopped and even reversed if the National Bank announced a new series of note auctions early next week.
"Yields could even edge up, if the National Bank announced a large note issue next week," Fedosenko said.
